moves.1. e4 c5: as always, 3+10 blitz on the menu...
moves.2. Be2 g6 3. Nf3 Bg7 4. d3 e6 5. c3 Ne7: the Hungarian variation, in the Sicilian: although the setup does not always run so smoothly; White has no desire to interfere...
moves.7. d4 cxd4 8. cxd4 d5: as always, the objective: d5 in the center...
moves.13. Bd2 a5 14. bxa5 Nxa5 15. Nxb5 Nc4 16: Black has sacced a pawn for play, and is now attacking Nb5: sort of; Bc6 is only just covered...
moves.19. Nd6 Nf5 20. Nb3: after Qxc6, Qxd2: so this was to be expected...
moves.20... Qb4: winning a usefull tempo: both Nb3 and d4 are under attack; Whites' center is cracking...
moves.21. Nc5: of course, White had better: he is not paying attention; this will cost material: Nf5xd4xe2+, is already very troublesome for White...
moves.21... Qxd4 22. Rd1 Qb4 23. g4: very dangerous: again, White underestimates the gravity of the situation; in retrospect, this is the losing move...
moves.23... Nxd6 24. exd6 Bxa1: of course, exd6 is forced: White cannot allow the loss of a full piece; after Qxa1, Qxc5, and also d6 is lost...
moves.25. d7: so this should make sense: but this is no problem for Black; yet...
moves.25... Qb2 26. Qf4: after Qxa1, Qxe2: this is not a very strong reply...
moves.26... e5 27. Qf6 Qxe2 28. Rxa1 Qxg4+: maybe a bit lucky: but luck is always forced...
moves.29. Kf1 Bxd7: Black kills two flies in one swat: also a4 is in trouble...
moves.30. Nxd7 Qxd7 31. Qxe5 Rae8 32. Qf6 Qh3+: forcing the White King into a lost position...
moves.34. Qb2 Rfe8: with this, White resigned: there is always a defense against Re1+; but with a Rook and pawn behind and the King exposed, White will always lose this...
